subject: Politics
title: Agenda Setting
description: A quick win: understand Agenda Setting.

hook.text: Media can't tell you what to think. But it absolutely tells you what to think about. That power is enormous.

buildup.text: Agenda setting means the media decides which issues get public attention by choosing what to cover and what to ignore.

discovery.text: Studies show that issues covered heavily in news become the public's top priorities â€” even if nothing changed.

twist.text: What media ignores disappears from politics. Climate change was barely covered for decades despite growing evidence.

climax.text: Politicians compete for media attention because coverage equals relevance. No coverage means political death.

punchline.text: The media's power isn't opinion. It's attention. What it covers matters most.

quiz.question: What does 'agenda setting' mean in media theory?
options: Media determines which issues the public considers important
Journalists tell people exactly what opinions to hold
Politicians directly control all news coverage
